case_name: Messrs. Burn and Co. Limited v. Workmen of Messrs. Burn and Co. Limited

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 195 and 196 of 1959 were filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 195 and 196 of 1959. Appeals by special leave from the Award dated April 15, 1957, of the Third Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, in Case No. VIII-7 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeals are from the Award dated April 15, 1957 of the Third Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Case No. VIII-7 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the Award dated April 15, 1957, of the Third Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, in Case No. VIII-7 of 1956. Sen, P. K. Chakravarty and B. N. Ghosh, for the appellants  in C. A. No. 195 of 59  and respondents  in C. A. No. 196 of 59 .

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 30, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. March 30. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-These are two appeals by special leave against the same award of the Third Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal and shall be disposed of by this judgment.

facts.text: Appeal No. 195 is by Messrs. Burn and Co. Limited called the company.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 195 is by Messrs. Burn and Co. Limited  hereinafter called the companypany  and Appeal No. 196 is by the workmen of Messrs. Burn and Co. Limited  hereinafter called the workmen . There were disputes between the companypany and the workmen on various matters, which were referred to the tribunal for adjudication.

facts.text: Appeal No. 196 is by the workmen of Messrs. Burn and Co. Limited.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 195 is by Messrs. Burn and Co. Limited  hereinafter called the companypany  and Appeal No. 196 is by the workmen of Messrs. Burn and Co. Limited  hereinafter called the workmen . There were disputes between the companypany and the workmen on various matters, which were referred to the tribunal for adjudication. Of these disputes, only two number survive in the two appeals.

facts.text: There were disputes between the company and the workmen on various matters referred to the tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: There were disputes between the companypany and the workmen on various matters, which were referred to the tribunal for adjudication. Of these disputes, only two number survive in the two appeals. The companypanys appeal is with respect to that part of the award which deals with incentive bonus to the clerical and subordinate staff while the workmens appeal is with respect to that part of the award which appeals with the cash benefit of Annas eight per head per working day for the period the canteen was number in operation.

facts.text: Company's appeal concerns incentive bonus to clerical and subordinate staff.

anchor.surface_text: The companypanys appeal is with respect to that part of the award which deals with incentive bonus to the clerical and subordinate staff while the workmens appeal is with respect to that part of the award which appeals with the cash benefit of Annas eight per head per working day for the period the canteen was number in operation. We shall first take up the companypanys appeal.

facts.text: Workmen's appeal concerns cash benefit of Annas eight per head per working day for period canteen was not in operation.

anchor.surface_text: while the workmens appeal is with respect to that part of the award which appeals with the cash benefit of Annas eight per head per working day for the period the canteen was number in operation. We shall first take up the companypanys appeal. The companypany has introduced incentive bonus for manual workers including Sarkars and Checkers but there is numberprovision for incentive bonus to the clerical and subordinate staff.

facts.text: Company introduced incentive bonus for manual workers including Sarkars and Checkers but no provision for clerical and subordinate staff.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany has introduced incentive bonus for manual workers including Sarkars and Checkers but there is numberprovision for incentive bonus to the clerical and subordinate staff. The workmen therefore claimed that these two categories should also be given incentive bonus like the manual workers and pointed out that in other companycerns this was done.

facts.text: Workmen claimed incentive bonus for clerical and subordinate staff like manual workers, pointing to other concerns.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen therefore claimed that these two categories should also be given incentive bonus like the manual workers and pointed out that in other companycerns this was done. The companypany resisted the claim on two grounds  i  that the clerical staff got what is known as the Bengal Chamber of Commerce dearness allowance, which is higher than, the dearness allowance paid to the manual workers and  ii  that the clerical staff and the subordinate staff do number actually produce anything

facts.text: Company resisted claim because clerical staff got higher Bengal Chamber of Commerce dearness allowance than manual workers.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany resisted the claim on two grounds  i  that the clerical staff got what is known as the Bengal Chamber of Commerce dearness allowance, which is higher than, the dearness allowance paid to the manual workers and  ii  that the clerical staff and the subordinate staff do number actually produce anything and if they are given incentive bonus it will mean that they would be paid on the production of others, namely, the manual workers.

facts.text: Company resisted claim because clerical and subordinate staff do not actually produce anything.

anchor.surface_text: and  ii  that the clerical staff and the subordinate staff do number actually produce anything and if they are given incentive bonus it will mean that they would be paid on the production of others, namely, the manual workers. The tribunal was of the view that the fact that the clerks got the Bengal Chamber of Commerce dearness allowance was numberreason for their total exclusion from the benefit of the incentive bonus scheme.

facts.text: Tribunal held higher DA not reason for total exclusion of clerical staff from incentive bonus.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal was of the view that the fact that the clerks got the Bengal Chamber of Commerce dearness allowance was numberreason for their total exclusion from the benefit of the incentive bonus scheme. It also pointed out that the subordinate staff did number get the Bengal Chamber of Commerce dearness allowance and there was numberdifference between their dearness allowance and the dearness allowance of the manual workers.

facts.text: Subordinate staff did not get Bengal Chamber of Commerce dearness allowance, no difference from manual workers' DA.

anchor.surface_text: It also pointed out that the subordinate staff did number get the Bengal Chamber of Commerce dearness allowance and there was numberdifference between their dearness allowance and the dearness allowance of the manual workers. Further the tribunal was companyscious of the fact that the clerical staff and the subordinate staff do number directly produce goods but that in its opinion was numberjustification for their total exclusion,

facts.text: Other comparable concerns like Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. at Burnpur, Bridge and Roof Co. India Limited, Howrah, and Tatas pay incentive bonus to clerical and subordinate staff.

anchor.surface_text: particularly when other companyparable companycerns like the Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. at Burnpur, Bridge and Roof Co.  India  Limited, Howrah, and Tatas were paying incentive bonus to the clerical and subordinate staff also. It therefore ordered that the companypany should extend the scheme of incentive bonus to the clerical and subordinate staff also and lay down the rates and companyditions for the same.

facts.text: Tribunal ordered company to extend incentive bonus scheme to clerical and subordinate staff and lay down rates and conditions.

anchor.surface_text: It therefore ordered that the companypany should extend the scheme of incentive bonus to the clerical and subordinate staff also and lay down the rates and companyditions for the same. The main companytention of the companypany before us is that as the clerical staff and the subordinate staff have numberpart in actual production they should number be given any incentive bonus,

facts.text: Tiffin allowance of annas eight per head per working day was granted by award dated July 24, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: All that we need say is that the companyrespondence between the workmen and the companypany shows that though the workmen were keen on the provision of a canteen before the tiffin allowance was granted by the award dated July 24, 1953, their keenness disappeared after the award.

facts.text: Workmen were keen on provision of canteen before 1953 award, keenness disappeared after.

anchor.surface_text: the companyrespondence between the workmen and the companypany shows that though the workmen were keen on the provision of a canteen before the tiffin allowance was granted by the award dated July 24, 1953, their keenness disappeared after the award. The companypany seems to have taken steps even before the award to start a canteen and pursued the matter vigorously after the award but the workmen started objecting to the arrangements made and some of the objections were fantastic.

facts.text: Company took steps to start canteen before 1953 award and pursued vigorously after.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany seems to have taken steps even before the award to start a canteen and pursued the matter vigorously after the award but the workmen started objecting to the arrangements made and some of the objections were fantastic. It seems that having been given the tiffin allowance they preferred to have it rather than go to the canteen.

facts.text: Workmen objected to canteen arrangements after 1953 award, some objections fantastic.

anchor.surface_text: pursued the matter vigorously after the award but the workmen started objecting to the arrangements made and some of the objections were fantastic. It seems that having been given the tiffin allowance they preferred to have it rather than go to the canteen. In the circumstances we are of opi- nion that the companyclusion of the tribunal is companyrect and there is numberreason for interference.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected workmen's claim for eight annas tiffin allowance during period canteen not working.

anchor.surface_text: Nothing has been brought to our numberice which would induce us to interfere with the companysidered order of the tribunal in this behalf. All the points that Sri Chatterjee has raised on behalf of the workmen have been dealt with by the tribunal and the companyclusion it has reached is that halving regard to the circumstances, the workmen were number eligible to the tiffin allowance of annas eight per head per working day.

1959. Appeals by special leave from the Award dated April 15, 1957, of the Third Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, in Case No. VIII-7 of 1956. Sen, P. K. Chakravarty and B. N. Ghosh, for the appellants  in C. A. No. 195 of 59  and respondents  in C. A. No. 196 of 59 .

WANCHOO, J.-These are two appeals by special leave against the same award of the Third Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal and shall be disposed of by this judgment. Appeal No. 195 is by Messrs. Burn and Co. Limited  hereinafter called the companypany  and Appeal No. 196 is by the workmen of Messrs. Burn and Co. Limited  hereinafter called the workmen .

companypany that the introduction of incentive bonus is a management function and the tribunal should number impose it on the management and reference in this companynection has been made to Messrs. Titaghur Paper Mills Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen  1 . In the present case, however, the incentive bonus scheme has already been introduced by the companypany for the major part of its workmen and all that is number asked for is that the benefit of the scheme should be extended to the remainder of the workmen.

concepts.interpretation: Distinguished because incentive bonus scheme already introduced for manual workers; extending to clerical and subordinate staff different from imposing new scheme for first time.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore see no reason to interfere with the order of the tribunal in this behalf Turning number to the appeal of the workmen with respect to eight annas tiffin allowance during the period the canteen was riot working, it is enough to say that this matter was examined at length by the tribunal. It has dealt with the history relating to this tiffin allowance and exhaustively companysidered all the points raised on behalf of the workmen. Nothing has been brought to our notice which would induce us to interfere with the companysidered order of the tribunal in this behalf. All the points that Sri Chatterjee has raised on behalf of the workmen have been dealt with by the tribunal and the conclusion it has reached is that halving regard to the circumstances, the workmen were number eligible to the tiffin allowance of annas eight per head per working day. All that we need say is that the companyrespondence between the workmen and the companypany shows that though the workmen were keen on the provision of a canteen before the tiffin allowance was granted by the award dated July 24, 1953, their keenness disappeared after the award. The companypany seems to have taken steps even before the award to start a canteen and pursued the matter vigorously after the award but the workmen started objecting to the arrangements made and some of the objections were fantastic. It seems that having been given the tiffin allowance they preferred to have it rather than go to the canteen. In the circumstances we are of opi- nion that the companyclusion of the tribunal is correct and there is numberreason for interference.

outcome.relief_summary: Both appeals dismissed; no interference with tribunal's award on incentive bonus for clerical and subordinate staff or on tiffin allowance.

CONST_ART136 grounds the holding of no reason to interfere with the tribunal's order, as it provides discretionary jurisdiction to the Supreme Court under which such decisions are made.
CONST_ART136 grounds the holding that the tribunal's conclusion is correct and there is no reason for interference, reflecting the discretionary power.
CONST_ART136 addresses the issue of extending the incentive bonus scheme, as it is the basis for Supreme Court jurisdiction over the special leave petition concerning this matter.
CONST_ART136 addresses the issue of cash benefit for canteen non-operation, as it is the basis for Supreme Court jurisdiction over the special leave petition concerning this matter.

The merits holding on no exclusion from bonus supports the decision not to interfere with tribunal.
The holding that there is no reason to exclude clerical staff from incentive bonus directly addresses the issue of extending the scheme to them.

anchor.surface_text: But there can be numberdoubt that economically speaking the clerical staff and the subordinate staff also take part in the production and there is numberreason therefore for excluding them altogether from the scheme of incentive bonus. Besides, as the tribunal has pointed out, in other

We therefore see no reason to interfere with the order of the tribunal in this behalf Turning number to the appeal of the workmen with respect to eight annas tiffin allowance during the period the canteen was riot working, it is enough to say that this matter was examined at length by the tribunal. It has dealt with the history relating to this tiffin allowance and exhaustively companysidered all the points raised on behalf of the workmen. Nothing has been brought to our notice which would induce us to interfere with the companysidered order of the tribunal in this behalf. All the points that Sri Chatterjee has raised on behalf of the workmen have been dealt with by the tribunal and the conclusion it has reached is that halving regard to the circumstances, the workmen were number eligible to the tiffin allowance of annas eight per head per working day. All that we need say is that the companyrespondence between the workmen and the companypany shows that though the workmen were keen on the provision of a canteen before the tiffin allowance was granted by the award dated July 24, 1953, their keenness disappeared after the award. The companypany seems to have taken steps even before the award to start a canteen and pursued the matter vigorously after the award but the workmen started objecting to the arrangements made and some of the objections were fantastic. It seems that having been given the tiffin allowance they preferred to have it rather than go to the canteen. In the circumstances we are of opi- nion that the companyclusion of the tribunal is correct and there is numberreason for interference.

edges.explanation: The merits holding on dearness allowance not depriving bonus supports the decision not to interfere.
The holding that higher dearness allowance is no reason to deprive incentive benefits addresses the issue of extending the bonus scheme to clerical staff.

It has dealt with the history relating to this tiffin allowance and exhaustively companysidered all the points raised on behalf of the workmen. Nothing has been brought to our notice which would induce us to interfere with the companysidered order of the tribunal in this behalf. All the points that Sri Chatterjee has raised on behalf of the workmen have been dealt with by the tribunal and the conclusion it has reached is that halving regard to the circumstances, the workmen were number eligible to the tiffin allowance of annas eight per head per working day. All that we need say is that the companyrespondence between the workmen and the companypany shows that though the workmen were keen on the provision of a canteen before the tiffin allowance was granted by the award dated July 24, 1953, their keenness disappeared after the award. The companypany seems to have taken steps even before the award to start a canteen and pursued the matter vigorously after the award but the workmen started objecting to the arrangements made and some of the objections were fantastic. anchor.surface_text: This prayer is, in our opinion, very different from asking a tribunal to impose an incentive bonus scheme for the first time in a companycern. We can see numberreason why where an incentive bonus is in force in a companycern for the majority of its workmen, the tribunal

We therefore see no reason to interfere with the order of the tribunal in this behalf Turning number to the appeal of the workmen with respect to eight annas tiffin allowance during the period the canteen was riot working, it is enough to say that this matter was examined at length by the tribunal. It has dealt with the history relating to this tiffin allowance and exhaustively companysidered all the points raised on behalf of the workmen. Nothing has been brought to our notice which would induce us to interfere with the companysidered order of the tribunal in this behalf. All the points that Sri Chatterjee has raised on behalf of the workmen have been dealt with by the tribunal and the conclusion it has reached is that halving regard to the circumstances, the workmen were number eligible to the tiffin allowance of annas eight per head per working day. All that we need say is that the companyrespondence between the workmen and the companypany shows that though the workmen were keen on the provision of a canteen before the tiffin allowance was granted by the award dated July 24, 1953, their keenness disappeared after the award. The companypany seems to have taken steps even before the award to start a canteen and pursued the matter vigorously after the award but the workmen started objecting to the arrangements made and some of the objections were fantastic. It seems that having been given the tiffin allowance they preferred to have it rather than go to the canteen. In the circumstances we are of opi- nion that the companyclusion of the tribunal is correct and there is numberreason for interference.
